US MARKET WRAP – 10th December: UK PM May delays vote

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, treasuries mixed, dollar up, crude down.   

* REAR-VIEW: UK PM May delays Tuesday’s meaningful vote, Qualcomm wins prelim court hearing over Apple, US to issue anti-dumping order on China’s aluminium sheets, EU commission preparing disciplinary procedure on Italy while still in talks.

* AHEAD: Australian NAB Business Confidence, UK Employment Data, German ZEW Economic Sentiment, US PPI Final, USD 38bln 3yr Note Auction, German EUR 3bln 2020 Schatz Auction.

 

* BREXIT: UK PM May delayed Tuesday’s parliamentary vote on her Brexit deal after rumour that the government would have faced a substantial defeat. The PM will return to Brussels, ahead of the EU Summit later this week, to seek reassurance that the backstop will not be indefinite, which appears to be a major source of concern among MPs. European Council President Tusk said the deal, including the backstop, will not be renegotiated but stands ready to discuss how it can facilitate UK ratification. TD Securities notes that reassurance could come in the form of a non-binding legal opinion issued by the EU Commission stating the backstop cannot be permanent under Article 50; a letter by the UK and Irish governments on possible alternatives on the backstop arrangements; a vote in parliament on the implementation of a backstop. There is no set timing on when the vote will be delayed to as this will depend on negotiations while PM pledged MPs they will have a say on her deal by January 21st, the latest possible date a deal can be put to parliament. A source suggested the vote could take place in early January while Conservatives and Labour MPs pressured the PM to have a say before Christmas. Looking ahead, HSBC predicts three possible outcomes 1) PM May could call a vote of no confidence or one could arise if 48 letters are submitted to the 1922 Committee of backbench MPs 2) PM May could lose the no confidence vote or resign leading to a leadership context which might not solve the issue and delay the negotiating process 3) MPs could take control of the process from the current government, after the so-called Grieve amendment was approved by the parliament last week, opening the door to a possible second referendum, an extension of Article 50, a Norway option or a no deal exit. Elsewhere, the ECJ voted this morning that the UK can unilaterally revoke Article 50, without consulting the other member states. In later comments, UK Opposition Leader Corbyn announced the Labour party will not table a no confidence motion prior to the Brexit vote. According to TD Securities the likelihood is “that the deadlock will need to be broken by the general public, be it via a general election or a second referendum” warning that a late-February election could happen if called in the first half of January.

* TRADE: The US is to issue an anti-dumping order on Chinese aluminium alloy sheets.

* ITALY: Ahead of Wednesday, when PM Conte may present the revised budget to the EU, EU Commissioner Dombrovskis warned that time is very limited for Italians to make any substantial changes to the 2019 budget while EU’s Moscovici stated that the country has been showing more willingness to cooperate as talks continue though he is preparing the next steps for a possible disciplinary procedure against Italy.

* WTI (F9) SETTLES USD 1.61 LOWER AT USD 51.00/BBL, BRENT (F9) SETTLES USD 1.70 LOWER AT USD 59.97/BBL. Optimism from the OPEC+ deal at the tail end of the week has faded, and crude was defensive on Monday amid equities sliding, the DXY up. "The market is also continuing to digest the impact of the OPEC+ production cuts announced on Friday, with at least some significant slice of market participants unconvinced that a floor for prices has been established," Citi said. However, others were more optimistic: "The agreement is bullish for oil, first because it is a strong signal from OPEC that they are willing to step in to defend the oil price, and second because a cut of the magnitude agreed pushes global supply/demand from a surplus of ~500kb/d into a 700kb/d deficit (based on October levels and a call on OPEC of 32.4mb/d)." UBS said. UBS believes the recent slide in oil prices has been more a function of sour sentiment over the last couple of months, and argues that the OPEC+ agreement is bullish both from a fundamental and a sentiment perspective. "Together with data last week showing a falling US rig count and a decline in US crude inventories, sentiment may be poised for a swing into bullish territory," the bank adds.

 SPX +0.17% at 2628, NDX +1.05% at 6683, DJI +0.14% at 24423. SECTORS: Energy -1.62%, Materials +0.28%, Industrials +0.25%, Cons Discretionary +0.13%, Cons Staples +0.01%, Healthcare +0.32%, Financials -1.41%, Tech +1.42%, Telecoms +0.74%, Utilities +0.30%.

*STOCK SPECIFICS: Qualcomm (QCOM) opened higher after winning a preliminary court hearing in China, over claims Apple (AAPL) had stolen IP from it, Apple in turn opened lower following the ruling that China. Chipmakers (NVDA, INTC, AVGO, AMD) broke out of a 3-day losing streak. Defence stocks (LMT, NOC, RTN) outperformed after a new spending bill was announced from the Trump administration. Facebook (FB) announced an additional USD 9bln share repurchase programme pushing it higher on the open. PayPal (PYPL) traded higher following positive comments from UBS and Barron’s magazine. As oil retraced some of its gains from the end of last week, energy stocks (XOM, OXY, SLB, EOG, PSX, COP) fell too. FedEx (FDX) opened lower following a downgrade at BoAML.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE 2+ TICKS LOWER AT 120-22. Treasuries ended Monday’s session lower as equities rebounded and pared back some of their losses. The complex hit session highs at the European close on confirmation that PM May will delay Tuesday’s Brexit vote in parliament, before edging lower ahead of this week’s supply. Most of the action was concentrated in the front end of the curve were yields were higher by c1bps at settlement. 2s30s and 5s30s were narrower by c.3bps while 2s5s widened by less than 1bps.

* 3-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: The US Treasury will auction USD 38bln of 3-year notes (Tues), USD 24bln of 10-year notes (Wed) and USD 16bln of 30-year bonds (Thu). Analysts have suggested that demand at 3-year auctions has not kept up pace with the rising auction sizes. Barclays points out that bid-to-cover ratios have been trending lower in recent auction cycles (falling from 3.1x at the start of the year, to 2.5x at the previous auction; tail sizes have also been of note; in the first half of the year, 3-year auctions stopped through by 0.1bps on average, though in the second half of the year, has seen an average tail size of 0.3bps. Barclays also observes that direct bidder participation has also declined, falling to near post-crisis lows. “This was largely due to a smaller takedown from domestic investors, falling from 42% in October to 35% in November,” Barclays says, “broker dealers have had to take down more in recent months.”

* GBP: Sterling has endured yet another whip-saw session, as the UK government confirmed Tuesday’s meaningful vote has been called off. Cable finished the US session just off 1.2600 and a new ytd low circa 1.2606, while Eur/Gbp almost reached 0.9050 before pulling back just ahead of chart resistance around 0.9052, with the Pound sharply reversing from early peaks printed when the ECJ delivered its verdict on Article 50 in line with recommendations from a top EU legal advisor allowing the UK unilateral rights to revoke the withdrawal process. Note, broadly weaker than forecast data hardly helped the Gbp, but in truth it was all about the scheduled December 11 Parliament vote that looked set to be on even though the withdrawal agreement was widely anticipated to fail, but now seems destined for a delay to allow May more time to negotiate with the EU on the back-stop terms.

* AUD, NZD, CAD: Mixed fortunes for the non-US Dollars, as the Aussie and Kiwi managed to recover overnight losses made on the back of weaker than forecast Chinese imports and exports, but the Loonie lost ground alongside oil prices and failed to derive any support from better than expected Canadian housing data (starts and permits). Aud/Usd is slipped just below 0.7200 and the Kiwi under 0.6900 as Aud/Nzd meanders midway between 1.0455-1.0500 on the wide. However, Usd/Cad is back above 1.3400 having traded well below 1.3300 after last Friday’s contrasting Canadian and US employment reports.

* JPY: A gradual grind down from 112.25 to just under 113.00 for the Jpy after revised Q3 GDP revealed a steeper contraction in the Japanese economy than initially reported; the pair rebounded firmly above 113.00. Moreover, techs and option-related flows also underpinned the headline pair with a key Fib at 112.46 effectively splitting decent interest (1+ bn) from 112.40-50.

* EUR, CHF: Both showing relative resilience as the broad Usd rebounded from post-NFP lows (DXY extending gains above 97.100), with the single currency back towards 1.1350 and the Franc pivoting 0.9900 as Eur/Chf slipped from just over 1.1300 towards 1.1265 ahead of the next Italian budget presentation to Brussels (scheduled for Wednesday).

* EM: A bearish start to the week for most regional currencies amidst ongoing US-China trade concerns, as Usd/Cnh rebounded through 6.9000, Usd/Zar extended gains above 14.0000 and Usd/Try climbed above 5.3000 a significant miss on Q3 Turkish GDP.

analysis_details: • This counters earlier reports suggesting the House will have to vote on any decision to postpone the vote according to Conservative MP Duddridge

subject: ITV's Peston tweets "Labour and Jeremy Corbyn wont press no-confidence vote under Fixed Term Parliament Act till Theresa May has her chance to renegotiate her deal"
European parliament Brexit pointman says "we will never let the Irish down" in Brexit talks
Additional US Equity Stories - AAPL, QCOM, GT, AAL
content:
• Apple (AAPL) -  One of the co.'s LCD suppliers, Japan Display, has cut its December production of iPhone XR displays by 30% vs. November. Citi has lowered its price target on the co. to USD 200 from USD 240. (Newswires)
  • Qualcomm (QCOM) - A Chinese court has implemented an immediate ban on the sale of some models of Apple iPhones in China after an IP dispute with Qualcomm. Apple responded by saying all of its models were still available in China. (Newswires)
  • Goodyear Tire & Rubber (GT) - The co. is shutting all operations in Venezuela and offering its employees cash and tires for severance packages. (Newswires)
  • American Airlines (AAL) - The airline has cancelled over 400 flights due to weather conditions. (Newswires)

subject: Turkish President Erdogan's communications director says it is in the best interest of the international community to seek justice for journalist Khashoggi under international law
US Secretary of State Pompeo says China represent the biggest challenge for the US in the medium/long term

UK PM May told ministers she is heading to Brussels to secure a "legally-binding assurance" adding that the UK will not be stuck in the backstop indefinitely; according to The Telegraph deputy political editor

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 10th December 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Defence Names (RTN, LMT, NOC) – US President Trump asked Defence Secretary Mattis to prepare a USD 750bln budget proposal dedicated to 2020 military spending
  • KEYCORP (KEY) DOWNGRADED TO REDUCE FROM NEUTRAL AT NOMURA INSTINET
  • Travelport (TVPT) – The co. announced it will be acquired by Siris Capital Group and Evergreen Coast Capital in an all-cash transaction valued at USD 4.4bln

10th December 2018

DJIA

  • Procter & Gamble (PG) – The co. has had its price target raised to USD 104 from USD 99 at Citi, citing optimism after meeting with management. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • AES Corp. (AES) – The co. raised its quarterly dividend by 5% to USD 0.1365/shr. (Newswires)
  • Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) – The pharma co., alongside Vedanta Biosciences, are evaluating Bristol-Myers’ PD-1 inhibitor Opdivo with Vedanta’s VE800 to treat cancer. (Newswires)
  • Campbell Soup (CPB) – Italy’s Ferrero expressed interest in acquiring Campbell Soup’s International Business, which includes Arnott’s biscuits unit, in a deal that could be valued more than USD 2bln; according to sources. (Newswires)
  • ConocoPhillips (COP) – The co. announced its 2019 capital expenditures of USD 6.1bln; it expects a share repurchase programme of USD 3bln next year and anticipates shareholders’ payout to be greater than 30%. (Newswires)
  • Defence Names (RTN, LMT, NOC) – US President Trump asked Defence Secretary Mattis to prepare a USD 750bln budget proposal dedicated to 2020 military spending. Note a few months back, Trump asked to cut spending by 5%. (Politico)
  • Hess Corporation (HES) – The co. announced a 2019 E&P capital and exploratory budget of USD 2.9bln. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s writes that Apple (AAPL) could benefit from the ever-increasing money spent in the ecosystem rather than fresh iPhone sales and that investors should take this into account when valuing the co. (Barron’s)
  • Barron’s writes that PayPal (PYPL) is the underdog against Amazon (AMZN) for online sales, as most other retailers use PayPal to take payments online. (Barron’s)
  • Barron’s writes that Applied Materials (AMAT) has been oversold lately and is an attractive bet in the chipmaker space. (Barron’s)
  • Barron’s writes that Caterpillar (CAT) has been oversold and its prospects are “bright”. (Barron’s)
  • Barron’s writes that Lennar (LEN) has been oversold and it has strong growth prospects even in a slow market. (Barron’s)
  • Barron’s writes that Netflix (NFLX) and Palo Alto (PANW) are offering high growth at a discount. (Barron’s)

NASDAQ

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – A former employee at the tech giant has said that preventing media leaks is a number one priority for the co. (The Times)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – The retailer has dismissed employees in both the US and India after they breached data. Elsewhere, Wells Fargo estimates that the co. will be the number one seller of apparel in 2018. Also, it is planning a cashierless “Amazon Go” store in London as reported by The Telegraph. (WSJ/Newswires, The Telegraph)
  • Amgen (AMGN) – The pharma co. has raised its quarterly dividend by 10% to USD 1.45/shr. (Newswires)
  • eBay (EBAY) – The co. is launching discounts on thousands of products in celebration of “Green Monday”, one of the busiest holiday shopping days. (Newswires)
  • Electronic Arts (EA) – The video game developer has had its price target lowered to USD 105 from USD 148 at Piper Jaffray, citing expectations that the co. will have conservative guidance for the years ahead. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media giant has increased its share repurchase plan by USD 9bln in addition to its previously authorised USD 15bln programme. Elsewhere, BI reports that the co. is building a “hardware prototype testing facility” for communications hardware in the New Mexico desert. Deutsche Bank has said the co. is very attractive at its current valuation. Lynx Equity Strategies has shifted from a short position to a 'Long bias' on the stock. (Newswires/BI)
  • Gilead (GILD) – The co. has named Daniel O’Day chairman and CEO; effective March 1st 2019. (Newswires)
  • JD.com (JD) – Prosecutors are reportedly close to deciding on charges for the Chinese co.’s CEO Liu Qiangdong over rape claims. (WSJ)
  • Micron (MU) – Bank of America lowers EPS estimates for memory stocks and maintains Buy on Micron (MU) citing weak demand, spot price and Samsung 5G. (Newswires)
  • Monster Beverage (MNST) – Californian regulators have decided that the co.’s energy drinks do not cause cardiac arrhythmias. (Newswires)
  • PayPal (PYPL) – UBS have said that institutional investors are very bullish on the payments co. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – The electric automaker’s CEO Elon Musk has said in an interview that he does not respect the SEC and his tweets are not reviewed before being published unless they have potential to move the share price. (FT)

OTHER NEWS

  • Athene Holding (ATH) – The co. announced a combined capital development worth around USD 1bln in a transaction with Lincoln Financial Group and disclosed a new repurchase programme of USD 250mln. (Newswires)
  • Bunge (BG) – The agriculture and foods co.’s CEO Soren Schoder is leaving the co., Kathleen Hyde will become Chair of the board as it searches for a new CEO. Following the CEO departure, the co. is said to be open in reengaging in merger talks with Archer-Daniels Midland (ADM) and Glencore (GLEN LN). (Newswires)
  • Papa John’s (PZZA) – The pizza co.’s founder John Schnatter is exploring potential strategic alternatives for the co. (Newswires)
  • Tivity Health Inc (TVTY), Nutrisystem Inc (NTRI) – Tivity is acquiring Nutrisystem for a cash and stock deal valued at USD 1.4bln. (Newswires)
  • Travelport (TVPT) – The co. announced it will be acquired by Siris Capital Group and Evergreen Coast Capital in an all-cash transaction valued at USD 4.4bln. (Newswires)
  • Yelp (YELP) – The crowd-sourced review platform is being pushed by activist shareholder SQN Investors to review its business. The co. replied in an open letter saying that they “maintain an ongoing dialogue with all our shareholders”. (WSJ/Newswires)

Upgrades

subject: UK market mayhem awaiting official word on meaningful vote
content: Fast and furious price action, and quite frankly farcical goings on at No 10, as it seems like Tuesday’s Parliament vote will now be delayed even though PM May’s spokesperson and other prominent Cabinet members were insisting no postponement just ahead of the 11.30GMT conference call. Hence, heightened uncertainty and if an adjournment is confirmed at 15.30GMT then simply more uncertainty for even longer, which has given Gilts more impetus to set a marginal new contract best at 123.84, +48 ticks, while Short Sterling futures have been 4 ticks ahead and the Pound extended losses, to a fresh 2018 low at 1.2640 vs the Usd and hit 0.9035 on the Eur cross.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 10th December 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Mixed reports on meaningful vote deal leads to a meandering GBP
  • Risk sentiment remains soft, as trade uncertainty remains at the forefront
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US JOLTS, BoC’s Lane and BoE’s Cunliffe

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week lower following last Friday's sell-off on Wall St and Non-Farm Payrolls miss, with sentiment also dampened by disappointing Japanese GDP and Chinese trade data, as well as uncertainty regarding US-China trade relations. As such, ASX 200 (-2.3%) was led lower by tech and financials to print lows last seen in around 2 years, while Nikkei 225 (-2.1%) was pressured by a firmer JPY and larger than expected downward revision to Q3 GDP which had already been in contraction territory. Hang Seng (-1.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) were also negative after Chinese Exports and Imports data fell short of estimates and amid concerns regarding US-China trade tensions. This was after USTR Lighthizer declared the 90-days was a 'hard deadline' for China, while there were also reports China’s Vice Foreign Minister summoned the US and Canadian Ambassadors to China regarding the arrest of Huawei’s CFO and warned of consequences if she is not immediately released. Finally, 10yr JGBs were underpinned by safe-haven demand and with the BoJ also present in the market for a respectable JPY 1.2tln of JGBs with 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8693 (Prev. 6.8664)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer said 90 days is a 'hard deadline' for China trade deal and that new tariffs will be imposed if there is no agreement by March 1st. (Newswires)

Huawei CFO is to face prosecution in the US for fraud charges, according to Canadian court hearing. In related news, China’s Vice Foreign Minister has summoned US Ambassador to China regarding the arrest, while it had also summoned the Canadian Ambassador and warned there would be consequences if she is not released immediately. (Newswires)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Nov) 44.75B vs. Exp. 34.0B (Prev. 34.02B). (Newswires)
Chinese Exports (Nov) Y/Y 5.4% vs. Exp. 10.0% (Prev. 15.6%, Rev. 15.5%)
Chinese Imports (Nov) Y/Y 3.0% vs. Exp. 14.5% (Prev. 21.4%, Rev. 20.8%)

Chinese CPI (Nov) Y/Y 2.2% vs. Exp. 2.4% (Prev. 2.5%). Newswires)
Chinese PPI (Nov) Y/Y 2.7% vs. Exp. 2.7% (Prev. 3.3%)

Japanese GDP (Q3 F) Q/Q -0.6% vs. Exp. -0.5% (Prev. -0.3%). (Newswires)
Japanese GDP (Q3 F) Y/Y -2.5% vs. Exp. -1.9% (Prev. -1.2%)

UK/EU/US

UK PM May warned if Parliament rejects her Brexit deal, Britain could be left in the EU and the opposition Labour party could be brought to power. (Newswires)

UK PM May reportedly held discussions on Sunday with EU leaders as she anguished over postponing Brexit vote, in which she explained that MPs would kill off the deal and possibly her premiership, unless Brussels could hand her a lifeline. UK Brexit Secretary Barclay said PM May will not postpone Brexit vote on December 11th even though the government almost certainly faces defeat. (Newswires)

There were also reports that former cabinet ministers Johnson, Raab and McVey have all signalled a willingness to bid for the leadership amid speculation PM May will face a crushing defeat at Tuesday’s vote. (Newswires). In addition, there were separate reports that UK PM May reportedly faces prospect of 48 letters this week. (Independent.ie/Times) Furthermore, there are also suggestions that May’s cabinet is split over whether to stage a second referendum if her deal is rejected tomorrow. (Times)

UK opposition Labour Party Leader Corbyn said we have to respect the result of the referendum, while he added that PM May's deal is likely to be rejected in parliament and that no deal Brexit must be avoided at all costs. Furthermore, there were also reports on Friday that UK Labour party was said to be lining up rebel Tories for a no confidence vote. (The Times)

ECJ rules that Britain can unilaterally reverse its decision to leave the EU without consulting the other member states. (Newswires)

Irish Foreign Minister Coveney says the deal agreed between UK and EU will not change; adding that the backstop is a negotiated solution that both sides agreed on. (Newswires)

Telegraph's Steven Swinford tweets, The Cabinet conference call is being held at 11.30. Ministers are now assuming she will delay the meaningful vote. (Newswires)

UK PM May Spokeswoman says the meaningful vote will happen on Tuesday as planned, adding that PM May will update minister on her weekend calls with EU leaders. Spokeswoman added that PM May is confident she will win tomorrow's meaningful vote. (Newswires)

Faisal Islam of Sky tweets, EU27 source: “remains the case that there won’t be any changes to the Withdrawal Agreement but Downing St still working on an sop to backbenchers - saying they’ll be offered a ‘greater say’ on the backstop”. (Twitter)

UK PM May is said to pull tomorrow's meaningful vote on her Brexit deal; according to sources. (Newswires)

EU Spokeswoman quoting European Commission President Juncker says "we will not renegotiate Brexit" and reiterated that the current Brexit deal is the "best and only possible deal. (Newswires)

Owen Bennett of CityAM tweets, Source tells me the vote is up, backing up what is currently being said. (Newswires)

UK GDP Estimate YY (Oct) 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.6% (Prev. 1.5%)

UK GDP Est 3M/3M (Oct) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.6%)

French President Macron is to address the nation with an important announcement at 2000CET following street rioting and protests. Furthermore, it was reported that Macron is expected to announce tax reductions and subsidies to lower income families in an attempt to suppress the rioting (Newswires)

Italian government is to hold top-level talks today, while it was also reported that Italian PM Conte is reportedly seeking accord on 2% budget deficit and that Finance Minister Tria continues to seek a 1.9% target. (Newswires/Messaggero)

Moody’s affirmed Switzerland at AAA; Outlook Stable, while S&P affirmed Estonia at AA-; Outlook Stable and affirmed Iceland at A; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

White House Chief of Staff Kelly confirmed he has resigned, while his replacement Is to be announced in the approaching days. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European bourses are red across the board (Euro Stoxx 50 -0.3%) with the FTSE 100 (unch.) outperforming its peers amid currency effects (with the ongoing Brexit turmoil) and a boost by BAE Systems (+0.8%) following the Co. being shortlisted to build the next Royal Navy frigates. Over in Germany, DAX (-0.5%) is hampered by shares in heavyweight BASF (-4.9%) after the Co. significantly lowered their 2018 EBIT forecasts. Major sectors are largely in the red, with underperformance seen in materials in the wake of softer-than-expected Chinese CPI alongside further strain on US-China trade relations after the Huawei CFO is to face prosecution in the US for fraud charges as China demands her release.

Other notable movers include technology names such as Dialog Semiconductor (-2.5%) who are in the red in sympathy with poor performance in tech names overnight in Asia, while Standard Chartered (-1.5%) declined amid reports that the Co. was amongst the banks who have been misled by Huawei.

FX

GBP,EUR  – More volatile trade for the Pound amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty with all eyes on the 11.30GMT Cabinet conference call where Minister are now assuming PM May will delay the meaningful vote due to wide anticipation that the deal will be rejected in Parliament. GBP/USD currently languishing below 1.2700 ahead of the recently-made YTD low of 1.2657 having seen some reprieve following the ECJ ruling that the UK can unilaterally reverse Brexit without consulting the EU27 members. However, the upside was short-lived ahead of UK data which was weaker overall, with industrial productions considerably weaker than forecasts. Meanwhile, EUR benefits from the softer buck and pound with EUR/GBP near the top of a 0.8988-57 range.

NOK, SEK – Stronger than expected Norwegian inflation data just ahead of Thursday’s Norges Bank interest rate decision, weighed on EUR/NOK with the pair making a substantial move sub-9.7000 post-data with a low print of around 9.6500, before paring back a fraction of the move to stabilise around 9.6700. Conversely, further political angst in Sweden after the Centre party leader Loof noted that talks with Social Democrats have failed, adding they will not support their leader Leader Lofven as PM. This subsequently (alongside the NOK/SEK spillover) pushed EUR/SEK to session highs north of 10.3350 vs. a low print of 10.2973.

JPY – Moving in tandem with swings in risk sentiment more so than the wider-than-expected contraction in Japanese Q3 GDP, with USD/JPY currently nearer the highs of a 112.75-25 range with the downside contained  by big options (1.13bln at 112.40-50) and a fib at 112.46.

EMs – USD/CNY rose to just shy of 6.9150 in the wake of lower-than-expected inflation data alongside continuous US pressure after US Trade Representative Lightizer solidified the 90-day negotiating period as “a hard deadline” with new tariffs imposed by March 1st should the parties not reach an agreement. Meanwhile, TRY has largely recovered from the miss in Turkish GDP with USD/TRY clipping 5.3000 post-data before edging lower to around 5.2800. Elsewhere, ZAR is on the backfoot on a more technical note as traders cite the USD/ZAR breach above 14.2000 as the catalyst.

DXY – Still on the backfoot, albeit off worst levels, in a continuation of the move following Friday’s NFP miss with the index and broad dollar closer to the top of a 96.684-358 range and awaiting more impetus data in the form of JOLTS and employment trends.

AUD, NZD – Antipodeans deriving support from their softer US counterpart having initially wobbled on weaker Chinese trade data overnight. Kiwi hovers just below 0.6900 as the AUD/NZD remains capped ahead of 1.0500 and AUD/USD struggles to hold above 0.7200.

FIXED INCOME

Gilts were essentially unreactive to the disappointing UK output data and in-line GDP data, trading at the top of a 123.40-123.71 range with the UK benchmark driven mixed reports of the possible delay on Tuesday’s meaningful, with some support found from stock weakness. Bunds have broken the key 163.17 support level to the downside and hover around the 163.10 level vs. 163.02 at worst as technical factors have taken hold of the benchmark. This has squeezed the in-focus OAT-Bund spread, that has widened to over 40bps (double that of a month ago) with widening driven by the yellowjacket protests that have lowered the Bank of France’s GDP forecast by 10 bps, as investors look ahead to President Macron’s speech at 7pm. BTPs are outperforming and testing 124.00 to the upside post lower-house budgetary approval and strong output data, as reports circulate that PM Conte is reportedly seeking a 2% level with Tria looking for 1.9% ahead of  top-level talks today.

US Treasuries are essentially flat as yields hang above the 2.85% with support found at 2.78-80% as traders look forward to the JOLTS data and supply on the short end in the form of USD 39bln in 13-week bills and USD 36bln in 26-week bills later in the day

COMMODITIES 

Brent (-1.0%) and WTI (-1.3%) have retreated somewhat from gains seen after Friday’s agreement by OPEC+ to cut output by 1.2mln BPD from October levels for 6 months, with the deal to be reviewed in April. Russian Energy Minister Novak stated that Russia is to cut production by 228,000 BPD as part of this agreement. Separately, sources have commented that congress is increasingly likely to vote on the NOPEC bill, which will allow the DoJ to sue OPEC on anti-trust violations. Elsewhere, Libya’s NOC has declared a force majeure following a production suspension at the Sharara oil field due to safety concerns because of protestors at the oil field; which will result in a 315k BPD production cut, while Zawiya refinery is also at risk due to its dependence on the Sharara field.

Gold (Unch) has remained steady following Friday’s NFP miss which led to some speculation that the Fed may halt interest rates hikes sooner than was previously expected. Elsewhere, a Chinese government consultancy expects 2018 crude steel output to hit an annual record of 923mln tonnes

Iraq oil Minister Ghadhban says that the county's oil exports have improved after November's drop in exports due to bad weather

content:
Gilts were essentially unreactive to the disappointing UK output data and in-line GDP data, trading in the middle of a 21-tick range between 123.40 and 123.61 with the UK benchmark driven by Brexit jitters ahead of the key conference call at 11:30am amid suggestions the meaningful vote may be delayed, with some support found from stock weakness. Bunds have broken the key  163.17 support level to the downside and hover around the 163.10 level vs. 163.02 at worst as technical factors have taken hold of the benchmark. This has squeezed the in-focus OAT-Bund spread, that has widened to over 40bps (double that of a month ago) with widening driven by the yellowjacket protests that have lowered the Bank of France’s GDP forecast by 10 bps, as investors look ahead to President Macron’s speech at 7pm. BTPs are outperforming and testing 124.00 to the upside post lower-house budgetary approval and strong output data, as reports circulate that PM Conte is reportedly seeking a 2% level with Tria looking for 1.9% ahead of  top-level talks today.

US Treasuries are essentially flat as yields hang above the 2.85% with support found at 2.78-80% as traders look forward to the JOLTS data and supply on the short end in the form of USD 39bln in 13-week bills and USD 36bln in 26-week bills later in the day

subject: FX Morning Colour: Pound eyes conference call for meaningful developments
content:
GBP,EUR  – More volatile trade for the Pound amidst ongoing Brexit uncertainty with all eyes on the 11.30GMT Cabinet conference call where Minister are now assuming PM May will delay the meaningful vote due to wide anticipation that the deal will be rejected in Parliament. GBP/USD currently hovering around 1.2700 ahead of the recently-made YTD low of 1.2657 having seen some reprieve following the ECJ ruling that the UK can unilaterally reverse Brexit without consulting the EU27 members. However, the upside was short-lived ahead of UK data which was weaker overall, with industrial productions considerably weaker than forecasts. Meanwhile, EUR benefits from the softer buck and pound with EUR/GBP near the top of a 0.8988-57 range. 

NOK, SEK – Stronger than expected Norwegian inflation data just ahead of Thursday’s Norges Bank interest rate decision, weighed on EUR/NOK with the pair making a substantial move sub-9.7000 post-data with a low print of around 9.6500, before paring back a fraction of the move to stabilise around 9.6700. Conversely, further political angst in Sweden after the Centre party leader Loof noted that talks with Social Democrats have failed, adding they will not support their leader Leader Lofven as PM. This subsequently (alongside the NOK/SEK spillover) pushed EUR/SEK to session highs north of 10.3350 vs. a low print of 10.2973.

JPY – Moving in tandem with swings in risk sentiment more so than the wider-than-expected contraction in Japanese Q3 GDP, with USD/JPY currently nearer the highs of a 112.75-25 range with the downside contained  by big options (1.13bln at 112.40-50) and a fib at 112.46.

EMs – USD/CNY rose to just shy of 6.9150 in the wake of lower-than-expected inflation data alongside continuous US pressure after US Trade Representative Lightizer solidified the 90-day negotiating period as “a hard deadline” with new tariffs imposed by March 1st should the parties not reach an agreement. Meanwhile, TRY has largely recovered from the miss in Turkish GDP with USD/TRY clipping 5.3000 post-data before edging lower to around 5.2800. Elsewhere, ZAR is on the backfoot on a more technical note as traders cite the USD/ZAR breach above 14.2000 as the catalyst.

DXY – Still on the backfoot, albeit off worst levels, in a continuation of the move following Friday’s NFP miss with the index and broad dollar closer to the top of a 96.684-358 range and awaiting more impetus data in the form of JOLTS and employment trends.

AUD, NZD – Antipodeans deriving support from their softer US counterpart having initially wobbled on weaker Chinese trade data overnight. Kiwi hovers just below 0.6900 as the AUD/NZD remains capped ahead of 1.0500 and AUD/USD struggles to hold above 0.7200.

content: Pretty much in line with pre-Liffe open indications, the 10 year UK debt future gapped up to 123.52 and advanced a bit further before topping out at 123.56, +20 ticks, eyeing the FTSE, Bunds and confirmation from the ECJ that the UK can revoke Article 50 of its own accord. The latter briefly boosted the Gbp and weighed on Gilts (Cable up to circa 1.2760 and bonds down to 123.40), but the 3 month strip retains an underlying bid (1-2 ticks above parity) ahead of a relatively busy domestic docket for a Monday, and more importantly tomorrow’s key Brexit vote. Note, BoE’s Cunliffe is scheduled to speak today, but after hours and the event does not look likely to yield anything on the policy or economic front.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

10th December 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week lower following last Friday's sell-off on Wall St and Non-Farm Payrolls miss, with sentiment also dampened by disappointing Japanese GDP and Chinese trade data, as well as uncertainty regarding US-China trade relations. As such, ASX 200 (-2.3%) was led lower by tech and financials to print lows last seen in around 2 years, while Nikkei 225 (-2.1%) was pressured by a firmer JPY and larger than expected downward revision to Q3 GDP which had already been in contraction territory. Hang Seng (-1.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) were also negative after Chinese Exports and Imports data fell short of estimates and amid concerns regarding US-China trade tensions. This was after USTR Lighthizer declared the 90-days was a 'hard deadline' for China, while there were also reports China’s Vice Foreign Minister summoned the US and Canadian Ambassadors to China regarding the arrest of Huawei’s CFO and warned of consequences if she is not immediately released.

FTSE

BAE Systems (BA/ LN)/Babcock (BAB LN) – Co’s. are on the shortlist to design and build the next generation of Royal Navy frigates. Co’s. (along with a third bidder Atlas Elektronik) must submit specifications for five new frigates at no more than GBP 250mln each. (Times)

Standard Chartered (STAN LN) – Co. is reputedly among the banks who have been misled by Huawei over their dealings with Iran, according to sources. (Newswires)

BP (BP/A LN) – An activist shareholder group called Follow This, is to target the Co at the next annual meeting regarding their slow response to global warming. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Ted Baker (TED LN) – CEO Ray Kelvin is to take a voluntary leave of absence while allegations regarding his conduct are investigated. (Newswires)

Dixons Carphone (DC/ LN) – Co. and BT’s (BT/ LN) EE are in high pressures talks towards a new contract amid investor fears that Dixon’s could be cut off. Sources noted that discussions are positive but there is no guarantee that an agreement will be reached. (Telegraph)

BROKER MOVES

SMITH & NEPHEW (SN/ LN) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

SPIRE (SPI LN) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

RSA INSURANCE (RSA LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT JEFFERIES

DAX

BASF (BASF GY) – Lowers its EBIT forecasts for 2018 by a range of -15% to -20% vs Prev. ‘down single digits’, citing weakness in the chemicals unit as well as weak demand in China. (Newswires)

Bayer (BAYN GY – Elliott Management wants to split the pharmaceutical and agro-chem units. (Newswires)

BMW (BMW GY) – Alejandro Vukotich will be the new head of the driver assistance and autonomous driving development department from January 2019. (Newswires)

Continental (CON GY) – Co is considering acquiring software makers following the flotation of their Powertrain unit, which is expected in the second half of 2019; according to their CFO. Separately, CFO expects growth momentum to be stronger in H2 than H1; adding that the Co. will likely reach FY19 revenue targets. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – German government is prepared to facilitate a merger between the Co and Commerzbank (CBK GY); according to Focus Magazine. Separately, the CDU party says Germany does not need to take a stake in the Co. In addition Co has reported suspicions tax transactions to the German government. (Newswires)

Deutsche Post (DPW GY) – Co expects a decision regarding their planned price increase in the first quarter, from the German regulator. (Newswires)

Thyssenkrupp (TKA GY) – Co and Tata Steel are reportedly close to determining who will lead their planned European steel joint venture. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – Co has denied that Chairman Hans Poetsch was aware of emissions test cheating almost three months before US authorities made it public. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Rheinmetall (RHM GY) – Co aims to take a majority stake in KMW + Nexter Defence Systems. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

FRESENIUS SE (FRE GY) DOWNGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 10th December 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets began the week lower following last Friday's sell-off on Wall St and disappointing data from the US and Asia-Pac region
  • UK PM May reportedly held discussions on Sunday with EU leaders as she anguished over postponing the Brexit vote
  • Reports suggest former cabinet ministers Johnson, Raab and McVey have all signalled a willingness to bid for the leadership should May’s deal fail in Parliament
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German trade, Norwegian CPI, UK GDP, Production & Trade, US JOLTS, BoC’s Lane and BoE’s Cunliffe

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week lower following last Friday's sell-off on Wall St and Non-Farm Payrolls miss, with sentiment also dampened by disappointing Japanese GDP and Chinese trade data, as well as uncertainty regarding US-China trade relations. As such, ASX 200 (-2.3%) was led lower by tech and financials to print lows last seen in around 2 years, while Nikkei 225 (-2.1%) was pressured by a firmer JPY and larger than expected downward revision to Q3 GDP which had already been in contraction territory. Hang Seng (-1.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) were also negative after Chinese Exports and Imports data fell short of estimates and amid concerns regarding US-China trade tensions. This was after USTR Lighthizer declared the 90-days was a 'hard deadline' for China, while there were also reports China’s Vice Foreign Minister summoned the US and Canadian Ambassadors to China regarding the arrest of Huawei’s CFO and warned of consequences if she is not immediately released. Finally, 10yr JGBs were underpinned by safe-haven demand and with the BoJ also present in the market for a respectable JPY 1.2tln of JGBs with 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8693 (Prev. 6.8664)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer said 90 days is a 'hard deadline' for China trade deal and that new tariffs will be imposed if there is no agreement by March 1st. (Newswires)

Huawei CFO is to face prosecution in the US for fraud charges, according to Canadian court hearing. In related news, China’s Vice Foreign Minister has summoned US Ambassador to China regarding the arrest, while it had also summoned the Canadian Ambassador and warned there would be consequences if she is not released immediately. (Newswires)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Nov) 44.75B vs. Exp. 34.0B (Prev. 34.02B). (Newswires)
Chinese Exports (Nov) Y/Y 5.4% vs. Exp. 10.0% (Prev. 15.6%, Rev. 15.5%)
Chinese Imports (Nov) Y/Y 3.0% vs. Exp. 14.5% (Prev. 21.4%, Rev. 20.8%)

Chinese CPI (Nov) Y/Y 2.2% vs. Exp. 2.4% (Prev. 2.5%). Newswires)
Chinese PPI (Nov) Y/Y 2.7% vs. Exp. 2.7% (Prev. 3.3%)

Japanese GDP (Q3 F) Q/Q -0.6% vs. Exp. -0.5% (Prev. -0.3%). (Newswires)
Japanese GDP (Q3 F) Y/Y -2.5% vs. Exp. -1.9% (Prev. -1.2%)


UK/EU

UK PM May warned if Parliament rejects her Brexit deal, Britain could be left in the EU and the opposition Labour party could be brought to power. (Newswires)

UK PM May reportedly held discussions on Sunday with EU leaders as she anguished over postponing Brexit vote, in which she explained that MPs would kill off the deal and possibly her premiership, unless Brussels could hand her a lifeline. UK Brexit Secretary Barclay said PM May will not postpone Brexit vote on December 11th even though the government almost certainly faces defeat. (Newswires)

There were also reports that former cabinet ministers Johnson, Raab and McVey have all signalled a willingness to bid for the leadership amid speculation PM May will face a crushing defeat at Tuesday’s vote. (Newswires). In addition, there were separate reports that UK PM May reportedly faces prospect of 48 letters this week. (Independent.ie/Times) Furthermore, there are also suggestions that May’s cabinet is split over whether to stage a second referendum if her deal is rejected tomorrow. (Times)

UK opposition Labour Party Leader Corbyn said we have to respect the result of the referendum, while he added that PM May's deal is likely to be rejected in parliament and that no deal Brexit must be avoided at all costs. Furthermore, there were also reports on Friday that UK Labour party was said to be lining up rebel Tories for a no confidence vote. (The Times)

French President Macron is to address the nation with an important announcement at 2000CET following street rioting and protests. Furthermore, it was reported that Macron is expected to announce tax reductions and subsidies to lower income families in an attempt to suppress the rioting (Newswires)

Italy government won lower house confidence vote on 2019 budget on Friday. In related news, the government is to hold top-level talks today, while it was also reported that Italian PM Conte is reportedly seeking accord on 2% budget deficit and that Finance Minister Tria continues to seek a 1.9% target. (Newswires/Messaggero)

Moody’s affirmed Switzerland at AAA; Outlook Stable, while S&P affirmed Estonia at AA-; Outlook Stable and affirmed Iceland at A; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the greenback was softer in a continuation of the weakness from the US job data miss which added to recent discouraging releases and supported the case for the Fed to take a time out after a 4th hike later this month. This helped its major counterparts recover from the early pressure that initially saw EUR/USD decline below the 1.1400 handle on opening jitters and in which GBP/USD briefly tested support at 1.2700 ahead of PM May’s crunch Brexit deal vote tomorrow. Elsewhere, antipodeans also began downbeat as AUD/USD retreated below 0.7200 in the aftermath of the weak Chinese Imports and Exports figures but then recovered in tandem with the broad softness in the greenback, while USD/JPY underperformed as the risk averse tone spurred flows into safe-haven JPY.
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures consolidated after last Friday’s OPEC-induced price swings in which the agreement to reduce output by 1.2mln bpd for 6 months beginning in January lifted prices towards USD 54.00/bbl, where it eventually met resistance before pulling back to below USD 53.00/bbl. Elsewhere, gold remained at a 5-month high with prices kept afloat by a weaker greenback in the aftermath of the miss in US jobs data, while copper was subdued by the risk averse sentiment and poor China trade data.

Baker Hughes Rig Count (7/Dec): Oil -10 at 877, NatGas +9 at 198; total -1 at 1,075. (Newswires)

Russia Energy Minister Novak stated on Friday that Russia is to cut production by 228,000 BPD with cuts to take place from October level of 11.4mln BPD, which will be gradual and take a few months. Novak added that he hopes crude prices remain around current levels and that OPEC+ output can go up and down depending on market conditions, while he added that optimal oil price to balance the market in the future is USD 55-66/bbl. (Newswires)

Congress is increasingly likely to vote on NOPEC bill to allow DoJ to sue OPEC on antitrust violations, according to sources. (Platts)

China government research body said China steel consumption for this year seen at 820mln tons and is forecast to fall to 800mln tons in 2019, while it sees iron ore demand this year at 1.206bln tons and next year at 1.147bln tons. (Newswires)

US


Treasuries finished Friday’s session in positive territory moving in tandem with equities and after non-farm payrolls indicated fewer jobs were created in November contributing to the view that growth is moderating. The yield curve saw some modest bull-flattening with short date yields lower by c.4bps and longer date yields lower by c.2bps. Spreads were mostly steeper and 2s3s were mostly unchanged after hitting their lowest level in more than 10 years. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 1 tick higher at 120-24+.

Fed's Brainard (Voter, Dove) said gradual rate hikes "appropriate in the near term" and expects solid US growth next year although added that some tail winds are fading. Brainard also commented that a gradual rate hike path will increasingly depend on evolving US outlook and highlights a data dependent approach. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (Non-Voter, Dove) reiterated that the Fed should keep rates steady citing subdued inflation expectations in financial markets, while he also said we are at or above neutral today. (Newswires)

White House Chief of Staff Kelly confirmed he has resigned, while his replacement Is to be announced in the approaching days. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks slump as region reacts to Friday's US sell-off and NFP miss, disappointing Japanese GDP and Chinese Trade Data, as well as the US 'hard deadline' on China
content:
Asia equity markets begin the week mostly lower following last Friday's sell-off on Wall St and Non-Farm Payrolls miss, with sentiment also dampened by disappointing Japanese GDP and Chinese trade data, as well as uncertainty regarding US-China trade relations. ASX 200 (-2.0%) declined from the open and hit lows last seen in around 2 years with tech and financials leading the downside, while Nikkei 225 (-2.2%) is pressured by a firmer JPY and larger than expected downward revision to Q3 GDP which had already been in contraction territory. Hang Seng (-1.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.7%) have also declined after Chinese Exports and Imports data fell short of estimates and amid concerns regarding US-China trade tensions. This was after USTR Lighthizer declared the 90-days was a 'hard deadline' for China, while there were also reports China’s Vice Foreign Minister summoned the US and Canadian Ambassadors to China regarding the arrest of Huawei’s CFO and warned of consequences if she is not immediately released.

In FX markets, the greenback is softer in a continuation of the weakness from the US job data miss which added to recent discouraging releases and supports the case for the Fed to take a time out after a 4th hike later this month. This helped its major counterparts recover from the early pressure that saw EUR/USD initially decline below the 1.1400 handle on opening jitters and in which GBP/USD had briefly tested support at 1.2700 ahead of PM May’s crunch Brexit deal vote tomorrow. Elsewhere, antipodeans also began downbeat with AUD/USD retreating below 0.7200 in the aftermath of the weak Chinese Imports and Exports figures but then recovered in tandem with the broad softness in the greenback, while USD/JPY underperforms as the risk averse tone spurs flows into safe-haven JPY.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher on safe-haven demand and with the BoJ also present in the market for a respectable JPY 1.2tln of JGBs with 1yr-10yr maturities.
